newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi says case of bomb suspect in U.S. hands.
newsitem.headline: Saudi says case of bomb suspect in U.S. hands.

text.p: Saudi Arabia said the case of a Saudi suspect in the bombing that killed 19 U.S. servicemen in the kingdom was in the hands of the United States where he is being held.
"This issue is in the hands of the country that he had left and returned to again," Saudi Defence Minister Prince Sultan said in a rare official comment on Hani Abdel-Rahim al-Sayegh.
His comments were published in Saudi newspapers on Sunday.

Sayegh had flown to Canada from the United States. He was arrested in Canada in March where court documents identify him as the driver of a car that gave the go-ahead signal for the bomb-laden truck that blew up Khobar Towers in June last year in eastern Saudi Arabia killing the U.S. servicemen.
Canada deported Sayegh to the United States this month.

Saudi Arabia -- which is believed to have arrested scores of people over the bombing but has not revealed any information on the investigation -- has said it was following Sayegh's case, but has not indicated if it was seeking access to him.
Sayegh denies any role in the bombing.
